item.title: Cars & Climbing: Systems for Quantifying Performance at Hohbach Hall
item.description:
This exhibition was scheduled to open on January 9. Due to the recent storms, it has been pushed back to January 11. We apologize for any inconvenience.

Throughout history, enthusiasts have developed methods to describe and rate performance systematically. Based on archival collections at Stanford, this exhibit explores the genesis of these systems as means for quantifying experiences like the difficulty of a rock climbing route or the quality of the ride that an automobile provides.

This exhibit is free and open to the public during library hours. 

Plan Your Visit

  • Library hours vary throughout the year. The most up-to-date hours of operation are available here.
  • Visit our Access & Privileges page to learn what you will need to bring with you to gain access to the exhibition space.
  • Stanford has a large campus. Be prepared to traverse at least 0.5 miles during your visit.
  • Parking regulations are enforced from 8 AM - 4 PM on weekdays unless otherwise posted.

item.title: From Near to Far: a View of a Cold War-era Aerospace Engineer & His Company at Hohbach Hall
item.description:
This exhibition was scheduled to open on January 9. Due to the recent storms, the opening date has been pushed back to January 13. We apologize for any inconvenience. 

Jack Nielsen was Chief Scientist at NASA Ames, and founder of Vidya Inc., before founding Nielsen Engineering and Research. NEAR today is a division of AMA Inc., but the legacy of Nielsen lives on today in this exhibit. This collection is a rare look inside Cold War aerospace and weapons technology, as well as technical report literature from governments and companies.

This exhibit is free and open to the public during library hours. 

Plan Your Visit

  • Library hours vary throughout the year. Green Library's hours of operation are available here.  
  • Visit our Access & Privileges page to learn what you will need to bring with you to gain access to the exhibition space.
  • Stanford has a large campus. Be prepared to traverse at least 0.5 miles during your visit. 
  • Parking regulations are enforced from 8 AM - 4 PM on weekdays unless otherwise posted.

item.title: From NEAR To Far - Exhibit Talk at Hohbach Hall
item.description:
Jack Nielsen was Chief Scientist at NASA Ames, and founder of Vidya Inc., before founding Nielsen Engineering and Research. NEAR today is a division of AMA Inc., but the legacy of Nielsen lives on today in this exhibit. This collection is a rare look inside Cold War aerospace and weapons technology, as well as technical report literature from governments and companies.

Join us on Monday February 27 for a discussion about the exhibit, and its connection to Silicon Valley History. This exhibit is free and open to the public during library hours. Visitors to the library will need to register upon entry, following all visitor entrance guidelines.

item.title: Qualitative Data Workshop: Content Analysis with NVivo
item.description: Join Esha Chatterjee, qualitative data software consultant for Stanford Libraries, for an intermediate level class on content analysis.  Learn how to upload your collection of textual data for content analysis using NVivo software.  Esha will cover coding and other tips.

item.title: Prof. Sam Oh: The Korean Memory Project and Korea National Debt Redemption Movement at East Asia Library
item.description:
Dr. Sam Oh, Professor Emeritus of Sungkyunkwan University in South Korea, will present the Korean Memory (KM) Project, which provides similar services as Europeana and the Digital Public Library of America (DPLA). The KM Project will ingest data from more than 119 institutions. Its research team has been commissioned to design a metadata schema that will be interoperable with other global systems that offer similar services.

Dr. Oh will also discuss the ongoing efforts to preserve the archive of the National Debt Redemption Movement (NDRM). The NDRM, which includes more than 4,000 historical documents and other materials, has been designated as an UNESCO Memory of the World. Dr. Oh will discuss the development of standard procedures for archiving small- to medium-sized memory institutions.

item.title: Take a break, pet a dog at Science and Engineering Quad, Y2E2 Courtyard
item.description:
The Terman Engineering Library is pleased to have therapy dogs again this quarter. Please join us in the Y2E2 Courtyard on Wednesday, March 1 from 3-4pm. Dog and owner teams from Pet Partners will be providing relaxation and stress relief. In the event of rain, look for us under the covered walkway.

Image Credit: Michael Spencer

item.title: CIDR R Text Analysis
item.description:
Are you interested in analyzing collections of novels or journal articles? Do you want to understand patterns across collections of tweets or other social media data? In this workshop, we'll learn how to import, clean, and analyze collections of text with R using several standard text mining libraries. 

Register here

Prerequisites:

  • The Introduction to R CIDR workshop or equivalent experience.

Before the workshop, be sure to download and install:

  • R: https://cloud.r-project.org/
  • RStudio Desktop Free: https://www.rstudio.com/products/rstudio/download/

Workshop materials:

  • https://cengel.github.io/R-text-analysis/

item.title: The Photographs of Rod Dresser at Green Library, Bing Wing
item.description:
Stanford Libraries presents The Photographs of Rod Dresser, on view March 3, 2023, through May 7, 2023, in the Peterson Gallery and Munger Rotunda, Cecil H. Green Library, Bing Wing. 

The exhibition is curated by Roberto Trujillo; produced and designed by Deardra Fuzzell. 

NOTE: Exhibit cases in the Peterson Gallery and Munger Rotunda are illuminated from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. The exhibition is free and open to the public. Visitors are encouraged to call 650-723-0931 or visit the Library Hours page to confirm hours and access.

item.title: CIDR R Machine Learning
item.description:
This workshop provides a beginner-friendly introduction to machine learning vocabulary and concepts, quantitative data preprocessing for machine learning, and the SuperLearner R package.

Register here

Prerequisites:

  • CIDR Introduction to R workshop (or similar experience).

Before the workshop, be sure to download and install:

  • R: https://cloud.r-project.org/
  • RStudio Desktop Free: https://www.rstudio.com/products/rstudio/download/

Workshop materials:

  • https://github.com/EastBayEv/Intro_ML_R

item.title: CIDR Python Text Analysis
item.description:
This workshop will introduce you to working with text data using the spaCy and textacy Python libraries. You will learn to effectively streamline text preprocessing, understand word tokenization, sentence segmentation, part-of-speech tagging, and named entity recognition using a single document (a short excerpt from H.G. Wells's A Short History of the World) and across a corpus of legal documents. 

Register here

Prerequisites:

  • CIDR Introduction to Python workshop (or similar experience)

Workshop materials:

  • https://github.com/sul-cidr/Workshops/tree/master/Text_Analysis_with_Python

item.title: Tabletop Tuesdays at Green Library, East Wing, SVA Seminar Room (Hohbach 126)
item.description:
Save the date for March's Tabletop Tuesdays (theme and featured games TBD). 

Tabletop Tuesdays is a new event series held on the third Tuesday of each month. At these events, we'll feature a selection of board games and collection items from across SUL's holdings around a specific theme. Drop in to learn about the month's featured game(s) and/or try some of the board games we have for open play at the Silicon Valley Archives.

item.title: Tracing Sea Routes on Maps: A conversation on the European and Asian contexts with Sara Caputo and Elke Papelitzky
item.description:
Two leading experts will discuss the appearance and function of sea routes on European and East Asian maps, showing the interconnections of the early modern global maritime world.


We have all seen tracks marching across the oceans of a map. Have you ever wondered where they came from and why they are there? In this online event, Sara Caputo (Cambridge) and Elke Papelitzky (KU Leuven) will share their ongoing research on route lines on European and East Asian maps, respectively. They will each give a brief presentation, followed by a conversation moderated by Katherine Parker (BLR Antique Maps).

 

Trailblazers’ wakes: Ship tracks in Western imperial mapping
Sara Caputo, University of Cambridge (UK)

In the ancient and medieval European world, the seas on maps were trackless. The few extant itinerary maps never seem to extend their lines onto the water. In the sixteenth century, however, European mapmakers began to include route lines on their representations of the oceans. These lines were closely linked to the navigational practice of pricking a course on portolan charts. They may have also drawn inspiration from the routes that had long featured in East Asian maritime mapping. However, in a Western context, tracks became a powerful tool to recount individual journeys and establish imperial claims, in relation to developing notions of ‘discovery’. This half of the talk will include some material from Caputo’s forthcoming book, Tracks on the Ocean (under contract with Profile Books).

 

Red lines in the ocean: Sea routes on early modern East Asian maps
Elke Papelitzky, KU Leuven
Many early modern Chinese, Japanese, and Korean maps draw lines in ocean areas that represent sea routes. These lines appear on maps of a single country, of a larger region, or on maps of the globe. They serve a range of different functions from providing information about (imagined) travel to visually integrating East Asia into global networks, reflecting a perception of East Asian mapmakers of their countries being integrated in these networks. Setting East Asian maps in conversations with European ones shows that when map images shift context between Western Europe and East Asia, the function of the route-lines changes. In the case of East Asian maps, these changes further promote the mapmakers’ narrative of early modern East Asia not being isolated but being a part of the global, maritime world.

item.title: CIDR Python Machine Learning
item.description:
This workshop provides a gentle introduction to machine learning vocabulary and concepts. You will learn the basics for classifying text and images using the scikit-learn, lime, and tensorflow Python libraries. 

Register here

Prerequisites:

  • CIDR Introduction to Python workshop (or similar experience).

Workshop materials:

  • https://github.com/sul-cidr/Workshops/tree/master/Intro_to_ML_with_Python

item.title: SSDS Text Analysis and Machine Learning Group - Meeting 1 at 120F Green Library (Velma Denning Room)
item.description:
Every Friday in April, 1-4PM in 120F Green Library (Velma Denning Room)

Register here

Click here to open the book and get started.

  • April 7     Chapters 1-3   Gain confidence coding with Python to import, wrangle, visualize, and understand data
  • April 14   Chapters 4-5   Develop strategies to internalize basic principles for working with text and machine learning
  • April 21   Chapters 6-7   Learn best practices for performing text analysis within and across documents
  • April 27   Chapters 8-9   Explore new research possibilities with large language models
